title: In Memoriam : Well known East Lancs faces lost in 2025
body_text:
While we gather with family and friends to celebrate and have fun this Christmastime, many of us will also be pausing for thought and to reflect.
As well as being a time of joy, for most of us Christmas is also a time to remember loved ones lost during the past 12 months, and in years past, whose presence is always sorely missed at times like these.
Throughout 2025, across East Lancashire we have lost many popular faces and ‘local legends’, and as the year draws to a close, we feel it is right to remember them, and pause to hold them and their families in our hearts, as so many of us know how tough that first Christmas without a loved one is.
Please look through the gallery of those we have lost this year above, and read about them below.
East Lancashire In Memoriam 2025
Sport
Former Burnley FC Women manager Matt Beard died aged 47 in September. He only spent two months at the club, resigning in August, having had previous spells at Liverpool.
He was described as a “true champion of women’s football” having spent 15 years working in the game, including spells at Chelsea and in the USA.
Talented teenage cyclist Aidan Worden was killed while out on a training ride with his team when he was hit by a car in Blacksnape Road between Hoddlesden and Darwen.
Aidan, 18, from New Longton, had won national championships and had had a promising future in the sport.
Former Accrington Stanley captain Mel Widdop died in June, aged 83. From Blackburn, he spent six years at Stanley, captaining the club to five trophy successes in that time.
Tributes poured in following the death of Chris Bandell aged 29, following a long battle with leukaemia.
The Everton FC academy product played for Padiham FC as well as a handful of other clubs in the North West.
East Lancashire Cricket Club paid tribute to two former players in May.
Australians Bob Cowper turned out for the Blackburn club in the 1960s, going on to score more than 2,000 runs in Test matches for the Baggy Greens. He died aged 84.
Brian Bowling played for 24 years at East Lancs, taking more than 600 wickets, and was a familiar face at the club for decades. He was 92.
Blackburn Rovers stalwart Mick McGrath was one of the last survivors of the club’s 1960 FA Cup final side until his death in April aged 89.
McGrath played more than 300 games for Rovers and earned 22 caps for Ireland, and worked for Thwaites Brewery after hanging up his boots.
Tough-tackling Burnley FC defender Andy Wharton died aged 63 in April.
Born in Whitewell Bottom, he made 65 league appearances for the Clarets, and was part of the Third Division title-winning side of 1981/82.
Paul Round was born in Blackburn and went on to represent his hometown club for several seasons, before playing for other clubs in the area.
Comfortable in central defence or as a centre forward, he died in February aged 65. Round was one of the former players present in September 2023 when Rovers celebrated their 5,000th league match.
Media
In June, we tragically lost one of our own, the Lancashire Telegraph’s talented print editor Peter Magill, aged 49.
Pete spent his working life in the North West, including long stints on the LT both as a reporter and sub-editor. Colleagues described him as ‘exceptional and humble’, and his presence is still sorely missed in our newsroom in Blackburn.
Journalist Dave Ayrton also sadly left us this year, aged 83. The former LT scribe also worked for a number of other titles in the region, and was praised for how he passed on his expertise to younger reporters in the office.
BBC Radio Lancashire’s Andy Peebles died in March aged 76. He was described as a “font of knowledge” whether that be on music, cricket and more, and also DJed on Radio 1 and presented Top of the Pops.
Politics
Former Mayor of Hyndburn Linda Storey died earlier this month, aged 72. She served as a councillor for the Conservatives for 11 years, serving as Mayor in 2005/06, and was also made an Honorary Alderman of Hyndburn.
Colleagues described her as a dedicated servant to the borough, as a dedicated, lovely person through and through.
Professor Margaret Brazier, a leading academic lawyer, died in March aged 74 after a long battle with Parkinsons.
Known to family as Margot, she chaired three key government bodies during her career in law, and was presented with an OBE in 1997 for her work.
Close friend Lady Brenda Hale, the former President of the Supreme Court, described her as “fearless, brilliant, and an inspiration to generations of scholars”.
Clitheroe councillor Bill Holden died while on holiday in Malta in February, less than 12 months after being elected to Ribble Valley Council for Labour.
He was praised as a wonderful father and grandfather by his family and huge asset to the council, passionate about improving his local area.
Mohammed Khaliq, who served as a councillor in Blackburn for 12 years after moving to the UK in 1960, died aged 84 in February.
He helped establish Masjid e Raza in the 1970s, one of the town’s first mosques, working in the mills and on the buses before becoming a councillor in 1992 for Labour. His death was described as a huge loss for the community.
Local legends
Many people unlucky enough to spend time in hospital will have had the good fortune to meet Imam Mohammad Iqbal, chaplain at Royal Blackburn Hospital for more than 25 years.
He sadly died on Eid day in June from a stroke, as he prepared to lead the day’s prayers. East Lancs Hospitals NHS Trust praised him for his “compassion, grace and unwavering care” for patients and families.
February saw the passing at age 73 of Phil Taylor, one of the founding fathers of the famous World Black Pudding Throwing Championships in Ramsbottom.
The event now sees hundreds of people taking part and many more spectating, and has become a key fixture in the Rammy calendar, ensuring his legacy lives on.
Accrington lost one of its high street stalwarts in May, when butcher George Cropper died on his 82nd birthday.
He spent his entire working life in Accrington; 60 years on his butchers stall in the market, before moving to open his shop in Blackburn Road which he ran alongside his daughter Clare.
Claire said her father was a "truly amazing man" who was hugely respected in the town.
Military
Veteran of tours to Iraq and Afghanistan Damian Holden, 38, from Burnley, tragically died in October.
The married father-of-two was described as a gentle giant with a heart of gold, and had just become a grandfather for the first time when he sadly died.
Lovingly dubbed the oldest man in Rishton, Jack Taylor died aged 97 in June. After serving in Europe, Africa and the Middle East in the Army, he enjoyed a career as a chauffeur and HGV driver.
He was married to his beloved wife Babs for 60 years and harboured a love for classic cars throughout his life.
Veteran of the D-Day landings Alvin Ansell, from Accrington, died in March aged 100.
A radar operator during the Second World War, he was a sales rep for several companies after leaving the military, he was a well-known face around time, active at St Paul’s Church, and captivated schoolchildren with a talk on the war in 2016.
Fellow D-Day veteran Ted Davidson died in February aged 99. In Normandy as a 17-year-old, Ted, from Padiham, landed on Sword Beach, and later received the Legion D’Honneur for his efforts.
Popular faces
Luke Harden, 36, died in November after being found with serious injuries in Bacup.
A model and DJ, he was very well known in Bacup, and was described as “special” by his family, who thanked the community for the outpouring of love shown after his death.
Two people, both from Bacup, have been charged with his murder, with a trial scheduled for April 2026.
August saw the death of Madia Kauser in Witton Park, Blackburn. The 32-year-old mum of two pushed her daughter to safety from a falling branch in the park, tragically sustaining fatal injuries in the incident.
Her husband, Wasim Khan, said the family were devastated and paid tribute to his “beautiful wife, who was the best mother”. The incident triggered a Health and Safety Executive investigation.
Rossendale dad Ryan O’Connor, 30, suffered a heart attack while fulfilling a lifelong dream to visit a Thai Boxing camp in Thailand.
He was praised for the love he showed as a father, and a GoFundMe to help bring his body home raised more than £42,000.
Liz Stone taught at Sacred Heart in Colne and St Jon Southworth in Nelson after a career in hairdressing and retail.
She was praised for her dedication to her pupils, and sadly died in May aged 66 after battling Alzheimer’s.
East Lancashire Hospice offers a bereavement support service to people who have lost loved ones in the past three years, including one-to-one support, group sessions, and the Bereavement Support Cafe.
For more details on how to access this support, visit the hospice's website. It is available to over 18s only registered with GPs in Blackburn with Darwen, Hyndburn or the Ribble Valley.
Rossendale Hospice and Pendleside Hospice offer similar services to those living in Rossendale, Pendle and Burnley.
Spring North also offers bereavement support to children and young people in Blackburn with Darwen.
